content:
Access Firewall Make sure the Thunderbird program is set up as an allowed program.

In Thunderbird Please check you have the following set up:

  • In Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Web Content:
  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • Accept third party cookies: 'Always
  • Click on 'Exceptions' button
  • Add exceptions for these: outlook.com, hotmail.com or office365.com
  • Set it to 'Allow' each of above
  • click on 'Save Changes'

re : I have turned off IPV6 I presume you have set: network.dns.disableIPv6 to true

Error message "User Authenticated but not Connected" - If a valid user name is presented but an invalid password, the server accepts the login, but subsequent commands fail displaying that error message.

So please check to see what you have saved for that account in this location:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Clickon 'Show Passwords'

Do you see any saved passwords incoming or outgoing for that outlook account ? The Mail account Server settings and SMTP should be using Authentication Method: Oauth. So you should see an 'oauth://account...' line But do you see any other - if yes, then remove them. They may be 'mailbox://account... or Imap://account... or smtp://account

content: David Because the new version replaced the old version, I cannot find the old version number. I upgraded in response to a message from Mozilla. It did not involve separate PCs. I did not mention that I am using Windows 10. When I loaded the new version of Tbird, there were no messages in the Inbox i.e. the messages that I had read but not deleted. Also thee was no Address Book. However, there was a message from Mozilla to run a separate program to transfer the data from the old version. I eventually found "File>Get New Messages>for all accounts". I believe this should have been on display after I did the upgrade. I had to click on the 3 horizontal bar image on the top right of the screen which brought up a drop down menu, then click "View" then "Toolbars" then "Menu bar". What a convoluted way of getting a menu on display. This fixed my main concern. All I need now is how to delete the duplicate account for my primary email address. Currently, the emails are downloading into both accounts. Roger
creator: rclloyd

content: Ok, click 'account settings' from the 'hamburger' menu (the one with three horizontal bars), then highlight and click the account in left column that you want to delete, then on right side of screen there should appear a highlighted DELETE button. Click that. There may be an extra prompt to delete data. Tick to do that so the extra downloaded messages are also removed.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks David When I clicked on the account I wanted to delete, no DELETE button appeared. However, I did find that below the account in the left hand column, there was another label "Account Actions". When I clicked on this, a short list of actions was displayed. The last item was "Remove Account". Success at last!

creator: sync56

content:
re :/home/laurent/.thunderbird/bfhf3549.default/ImapMail/mail.ac-rennes-1.fr

Checking the selected account....

The mail account mail.ac-rennes-1.fr has a -1 at end of the name. That implies you have more than one mail account using same server. Is that correct - do you have more than one email address using same server? If no - you only have one mail account / one email address using that particular server. Sometimes, if thunderbird cannot access a specific set of account folders, it can create another - except it adds a number to the account. In the ImapMail folder do you also have another mail account called 'mail.ac-rennes.fr' ? If yes, then try this:

  • In Account Settings > Server Settings
  • bottom right 'Local directory:.....'
  • click on 'Browse'
  • It opens showing contents of current account folder - 'mail.ac-rennes-1.fr'.
  • Go up a level to 'ImapMail' and select: 'mail.ac-rennes.fr' and clickon 'Select folder'

then restart Thunderbird.

creator: patrick.guerisse

content:
If the picture you are referring to is this web page. (Yes, it is a web page served up by Google via Thunderbird)

The next step after that is to update your gmail account of your authorization and pass the result of the process to Thunderbird via the local host. However there are some caveats for it to work.

You must have cookies enabled in Thunderbird. You must have JavaScript enabled in Thunderbird. You must not have other software "consuming" HTTP/HTTPS connections on localhost. Things like development packages and on occasions third party antivirus products can cause issues with that. See https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20

Inthis response David suggested you delete existing passwords for the account. Did you delete any entries for oauth:\\ that mentioned the account username? You need to.

creator: markh2

content:
Disregard this. The next answer is better.

You can hide it but it's a Custom CSS job.

It's difficult to tell you exactly how without knowing the version of Thunderbird involved.

Open the config editor and find:—

toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets

If its value is false, double-click the word false and it will change to true.

In your Dad's Home directory will be a directory called .thunderbird — you'll probably have to press Ctrl-H to make it show in his file browser. In that will be a folder with a load of random letters and numbers in it's name; there may be more than one and if so choose the newest.

In that directory make directory called chrome, all lower case. Now get into that and create a text file called userChrome.css, again all lower-case apart from the C in the middle. That's the file that will hold the instructions to Thunderbird.

Paste this into userChrome.css:— #offline-status { display: none !important; } Restart Thunderbird to see if it's worked.

To find out what version he's actually on press Alt-H and click About Thunderbird and that will say. If the above doesn't work and you tell me that version I'll install it and find out exactly how to do it.

I absolutely share your feelings on the constant mending things that aren't broken. If there comes a point when your Dad has to 'Upgrade' it may be worth his looking at Seamonkey as that has been spared the vagaries of fashion.
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content:
HotMail/Outlook settings have changed and need up-dating.

Press Alt-e and choose 'Account Settings' from the drop-down menu that appears, then click 'Server Settings' under the Outlook account and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: outlook.office365.com  Port: 995 [993 for IMAP]  User Name: <your e-mail address>  Connection security:  SSL/TLS  Authentication method: OAuth2

  Now click 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' in the left hand column. Double click the 'Outlook.com (Microsoft)' entry and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: smtp.office365.com  Port: 587  Connection security: STARTTLS  Authentication method:  OAuth2  User Name: <your e-mail address>

content:
My personal suggestion: this is your career. I would'

  1. do full backup of thunderbird profile, normally at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird - copy anywhere while thunderbird is NOT running
  2. uninstall thunderbird
  3. do your tax accounting
  4. reinstall thunderbird and exit
  5. copy the backedup profile to same location as above

This isn't a perfect solution, but it gives you time to breath and do your thing. In the interim, you can always use your web interface. Unless thunderbird was embedded into your tax software, I am clueless on the problem. If thunderbird WAS involved/embedded into your software, then I recommend doing a backlevel to whatever version worked. Thunderbird cannot be accountable for how other products use it, so in such instances, it is best to keep the version that works.

creator: JonathanWexler

content:
er :FYI - my local folders are on a network drive

So not in the default location. I've come across various issues when profile or parts thereof are on network drive.

If file is on network /cloud then that involves a more complex operation as file must be accessed/downloaded first.

Compacting means opening original file, creating a new file, reading original file, copying each email into the new file providing it does not have any 'marked as deleted' markers - those emails are ignored. When finished, old file is deleted (eg: Inbox) and new file takes the name of deleted file eg: 'Inbox' and the 'Inbox.msf' file is deleted and recreated based on the updated Inbox mbox file.

You could switch off the auto compacting. Then manually compact any folders from which you either delete or move emails eg: Inbox, Drafts, and Junk/Spam tend to be the most frequently used folders that come into that category. If using Imap then Inbox can be set up to expunge emails on Exit of Thunderbird - Account SEttings > Server settings under 'Message Storage'

OR switch on auto compacting but force it to ask you first which means you could delay the action whilst you complete a task etc.

Advise - never allow any single mbox text file to be larger than a suitable size which a simple text editor program could open.

Advise - do not click on folders and view emails ect when compacting as it may interupt the process. Trying to access a file when it's being compacted is no adviseable. Never exit Thunderbird.

Personally, I prefer to have compacting set to tell me when it's required but I have control over when to use it. Then I go into Offline mode to stop incoming traffic, I set up to do compacting and walk away and make a cuppa. By the time I get back, all is done and I go back into online mode.

content:
Sorry for the delay in responding. Not been too good of late.

Anyway, let me try and explain a little better.

I have a filter on my server, which is hosted by a US company, and the filter works great for everybody except for Thunderbird.

What the filter does is, if an email address is used which begins with a certain phrase, this email is forwarded to a parent email address of those email addresses. I hope you're with me so far.

I then, in turn, receive these emails through my email client, Thunderbird, using the parent email address, which come through correctly, ie the from email address shows as the original sender and the to email address shows as the wild card email address that they sent the email to. The received email shows me who the email was originally from, then original sender, and who it's to, which is the email address they original sender sent it to. Note: this is the email address of the wildcard email address and not the parent email address. I might be losing you now.

When using my email client, Thunderbird, if I click reply it wants to reply to the parent email address of the wildcard email address that the original sender sent the email to, and not to the original sender, as it should be. Likewise, the from field is filled with the original senders email address and not the parent email address as it should be. I know I've lost you now because I've lost myself.

In my email client, namely Thunderbird, what it should be showing is in the to field, the original sender and the from field, the final recipient i.e the parent email account.

I hope I've explained it in a way that's more understandable although because it's such a tricky thing to explain, for me anyway, I will read it through again now and hopefully it means what I mean it to mean. And if you followed all of that, you're a better man than I am.

After reading through several times and making numerous alterations/corrections, i will now send and keep my fingers crossed 🤞.

Chris
